utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Hello everybody. I'm Jesse Watters along with Greg Gutfeld, Kennedy, Geraldo Rivera and Emily Compagno. It's 5:00 in New York City and this is THE FIVE. Soft on crime policies leaving a trail of avoidable death and destruction in Democrat-led cities all across the country. Dangerous criminals who should be behind bars are set loose with plenty of victims to choose from. And liberal district attorneys don't seem to care, despite there being a tragic new example of their policies every single day. Like 24-year-old UCLA grad student Brianna Kupfer who was randomly stabbed to death while working in a furniture store in Los Angeles. Her heartbroken father blaming politicians for letting criminals run rampant.

utterances.speaker: TODD KUPFER, FATHER OF BRIANNA KUPFER
utterances.utterance: This kind of tragedy just can't befall more people. It's just so painful. I'm not blaming anybody by name. I blame -- what's endemic in our society right now is that everybody seems to be (inaudible) on giving back rights and bestowing favor on people that rob others of their rights.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Police think Brianna's killer is a homeless man who just calmly walked out the back door but said they are still trying to track him down. That is not the only example though of lawlessness. The wild, Wild West has returned to California, train robberies are up 160 percent in L.A. Tracks are littered with filth and discarded packages. The railroad companies blaming no bail policies that allow thieves to keep coming back. All right, Greg, you were around back when train robberies just swept the nation. So, maybe this is nostalgia for Joe Biden. You know, I remember when I just don't see how this could possibly be happening.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: He would care if this was Amtrak, you know that, right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because that's where he sits and tells everybody about corn pop. I get the feeling we're going to hell without the hand basket. You have Alvin Bragg, right? He's the Manhattan D.A. He's under fire for his pro- crime policies. How did he react when the public didn't like what he was doing? He didn't change course. He hired crisis P.R. He was more concerned about the perception than he was about human suffering. That would be like Exxon Valdez doing press conferences every day without ever cleaning up the oil spill. You know, this isn't about perception, it's about human suffering. Meanwhile, you know, that poor father, he is right. The response in all of the cities is a WCYD, what can you do, right? You can't lock them up because there are so many activists out there that say that is a violation of rights. And we have mayors that are more terrified of activists than they are of murderers. So, you have them piling on all of this context, right? When we do this show, we always complain about being taken out of context. In this case, the context needs to be taken out of the story because in the last decade we've allowed the media and activism to create a context for crime. A deranged male savage murders a female, right? Those are all -- those are the only variables you need. Once you start adding more, oh, it's about society, it's about inequality, it's about ineffective policing. Then what you do is you create leadership paralysis. Nobody can do anything. It's about the rights. And that's what the father said. It's about the rights of the person who murdered his daughter. Well, what about the rights of his late daughter and all of these Asian women that are getting killed? Perhaps if it was white supremacist, the media would care, but they don't right now. We have to drill down on the simplest variables in every equation. Deranged man on the street, women getting murdered. You don't need to add anymore context unless you are willing to hang out with a deranged male and explain to him how it's about society and inequality. Good luck with that. Right now we need to get these people off the streets and into institutions. One less thing, institutions, if they are closed we need to open them up. Geraldo gets a bad rap on this. He was focusing on the institutions that were abusing teenagers and young people with disease. We don't know where these other mental institutions. Why aren't they open? We just want these people to get help. We don't want to hurt them. We want them to stop hurting other people.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Is that a consideration in Los Angeles or throughout these metropolitan areas, Geraldo?

utterances.speaker: GERALDO RIVERA, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: There is no place for them to go, Jesse. Greg is absolutely right about that. When they deinstitutionalized the population once described as mentally retarded, those are kids with Down syndrome or severe autism.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: They needed to be in a small facility, a community-based facility. Here you are talking about schizophrenic, you're talking about bipolar, you're talking about people who've been deemed crazy who are off their meds. They have no place to go. They are vagrants. You know, Eric Adams is right when he says of New York and other big cities, the number one job of government is to keep people safe. If you don't give people a sense of safety and vagrancy is one thing of homelessness and aggressive panhandlers and the people who come up with the squeegee and the dirty rugs who wipe your windows, all those things were crimes that were enforced from the administration of Ed Koch on. And you know, in recent times have been ignored by these woke D.A.'s on one coast or the other where they say that these crimes are too insignificant. If you don't go for the kid jumping the turnstile in the subway, no one is going to use the subway because they'll feel unsafe. And then you'll have the nut job that pushes the Asian woman onto the tracks. You have to take care of the, you know, the small -- civic well-being. You know, we have to keep people not only safe but with a sense of being safe. We need a cop on every subway station, a cop on every train. Those tracks, those railroad tracks, the Union Pacific, didn't they use to be railroad police? Where's the company's responsibility? Why aren't they patrolling these container cars also? It just seems to me that law enforcement generally has been put on the back burner because of the handful of cases of police abuse. The law enforcement got a bad rap, and now they have overreacted and they are letting -- they're letting these punks do whatever they want to. And in the case of that poor father, what a kick in the guts that his daughter is stabbed. She's in graduate school, working hard. She's going to contribute to society and some punk, some bum, some piece of crap comes over and randomly stabs her to death and then walks out. I mean, this is untenable, is this small wonder that there is dissatisfaction with government.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Kennedy, you know the scene out there in L.A. You see I'm sure in the media market and because it's national, this beautiful young woman's face is everywhere. Her life is right in front of her, her whole life.

utterances.speaker: LISA KENNEDY MONTGOMERY, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Is there any feeling among the leaders in Los Angeles that we have to do something now at this point? Do they feel anything or do they just contextualized it like Greg said?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: It's interesting because some of them do. Alex Villanueva who is actually the elected L.A. County sheriff, he's been working tirelessly with his department to clean up these homeless encampments. So is Kevin de Leon who is an L.A. City council member, and its whac-a-mole. You know, you try. You clear things out, but the ACLU, they've taken the wrong side here. You know, there is a way of defending freedom. There is a way of pushing back against government. But what they are allowing these politicians to do is completely skirt responsibility. Brown is where I'm from where I raised my girls in Pacific Palisades. You know, she went to beach camp down the street. She was raised to do exactly what she was supposed to do. Her parents moved to a safe part of the city. She went to college. She was getting, you know, her masters in architecture. She was working at a high end furniture store learning more about her craft. She was doing what she was supposed to do. And so is Krystal Bayron-Nieves. She's a 19-year-old kid working at Burger King. She was doing the right thing. Same with Michelle Alyssa Go. You know, here is a woman who is working hard. Their parents are proud. Their parents raised them right. And now, you know, it's like they're victims. They're gone. They don't have a future. They're not going to have kids. And that's a travesty that we cannot accept. So, whatever these politicians are doing, they are doing it wrong. So I hope Todd Kupfer continues to speak out, continues to be the voice for his daughter and other victims who are forgotten.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Emily, do the lawyers own any of this? You cannot touch a hair on a deranged, violent, homeless man's head, but he can go around pretty much doing whatever the hell he wants in a society. Do the owners have to own up to what they did here?

utterances.speaker: EMILY COMPAGNO, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: Look, don't blame the bar, Jesse, but let me tell you who to blame. So Kennedy was mentioning the sheriff there in Los Angeles. That's the same sheriff that the prosecutor there, Gascon, called a pig. Geraldo said where is the government there with the train robberies up 356 percent? Where is the federal government? Interstate commerce and international commerce because 40 percent of our shipped goods go along that trail route there in southern California. That's DOJ jurisdiction. So the question needs to be posed to our president when they're allocating billions of dollars of your tax dollars to things on the streets, $5 billion for mental health. Well, why don't we see where our tax dollars should go? Because all of those families have zero child left. All of those families will mourn for generations where their tax dollars apparently went up in smoke and couldn't even provide for the safety while jurisdictions were fighting over things. And let me explain another policy aspect that leads to this. People talk about criminal justice reform. People pin it on bail laws and the like. When you re-classify crimes that is the heart of this matter. We all know the recidivist issue, right? Two-thirds of violent felons, they are arrested within five years of their original offense. That was before COVID. Now, that stat is even higher. So the notion that people who rob and battery and stock and engage in domestic violence and the likes, the fact that they go free, those are recidivist. That's why when we hear about these murderers, people pushing people off subway platforms, we say, who's surprised? That guy was arrested 16 times for battery and for stalking and the like. But now, stalking is not a felony. Now, battery is not a felony offense. That is where the problem lies. That's who we need to blame. Those politicians and those government elected officials.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm sure when they collar the homeless guy that slashed this young girl, he's going to have a rap sheet a mile long. I guarantee it.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Up next, Republicans are surging in the polls and it's making Joe Biden pretty nervous. Wait until you hear who the media is blaming though.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: President Biden needs a (inaudible) me up. He's desperately seeking a major reset after making the Republicans look great again. Support for GOP is booming to levels not seen since 1995, 26 years. Gallup showing a dramatic political shift after just one year of President Biden. Forty-seven percent of Americans now calling themselves Republicans while only 42 percent claim to be Democrats, 47 to 42. The White House frantically looking to write their ship after seeing these disastrous numbers, plotting a new communication strategy for the president, one that connects to all Americans they say. And don't you dare blame the president for his failures. Watch guests on CNN looking to shift the blame.

utterances.speaker: PAUL BEGALA, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST
utterances.utterance: He got infrastructure passed and that's a good thing because success can breed success. He is putting the full force of the presidency behind him. I think the problem for the Democrats right now is not that they have bad leaders, they have bad followers.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Bad followers, are you kidding me? We thought the pandemic was over. That's what it's about, isn't it? Isn't this disastrous approval, Greg, all are mostly about COVID, the failure to stop COVID?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think so because I mean, right now the Democrats can only drive in two gears, symbolic rhetoric and race shaming. So their muscles have atrophied and they can't really battle to fight the supply chain problems or the border or crime or inflation or COVID because they're just better at virtue signaling and getting great responses from Twitter. The most amazing truth about this, if you want to be more popular in America, be the party out of power. Remember, the party in power, the Democrats used to be out of power and they could strut and they could pontificate and they could rage. But now they are in power and they have to work. And now we're seeing that they are absolutely hopeless. But what if the Republicans get more done now because the Democrats are failing? A 14-point surge is pretty amazing. You're going to get more Congressional seats, more Senate seats, maybe more governors and you see these progressive policies being exposed. So, I think he should enjoy being out of power because those in power fail and you benefit. And the dynamic goes both ways. It will happen to the Republicans. Beauty of the system.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: President Biden is -- he is clearly failing on COVID and to the other items that Greg mentioned there, Kennedy. But he seems easily distracted. He seems disconnected. He jumps from Build Back Better to voting rights. Who knows what's next? You know, who's to blame? Is it him? Is it his staff? The White House chief of staff Ron Klain, Rasputin, should he be fired? What do you think?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Yes. I think he should fire them all. The only good thing about this is for those of us who saw this coming and have seen socialism take root and destroy other countries from North Korea to Venezuela. I'm just happy to see that American voters are snapping to their senses faster. That's the good news because they are not going to stand up for a lot of it. Geraldo, it's not just -- it's not just COVID because they have been lied to on pretty much every level. It's also inflation and not being able to afford things and having to make sacrifices deciding where you're going to spend what little money you have because inflation, as you know, is outpacing wage growth. And they can't fall back on, well, you know, wages are rising. Well, they are not necessarily when gas and meat cost twice what they did a year ago. This administration has to stop lying about things. They have to stop blaming everyone else for these problems, which is what Paul Begala just did. And they have to stop propagandizing, which is what Jen Psaki does every single day. Be honest with people. Let them know you are in a crisis. Let them know it's difficult. Tell them what you are going to do and then go ahead and do it and stop blaming the guy who is getting shorted for the problems that you've created.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: And yet, Jesse, Paul Begala did exactly what Kennedy just said. It's not bad leaders, its bad followers. They're trying to shift responsibility given the catastrophe of these poll numbers, right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Guys like Begala they get lucky, they latch on to a talented politician. He takes them all the way to the top. And then everybody thinks Begala is some wizard and they pay him a bunch of consulting fees for the rest of his stupid life. But if you listen to what he says when he opens his mouth, he doesn't make any sense. This guy is not responsible for any politician success. He just got lucky. Just was on the right place at the right time. Everybody knows what that's about, Geraldo.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Rest of his stupid life, ouch.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The country is tired of struggling. We have sacrificed a lot and it's been a very turbulent last couple of years. At this point, we want schools open. We want to go into a subway without getting pushed to our deaths. We don't want to be stranded at the airport for 17 hours because of a COVID mandate. We don't want to fill up the gas tank and have it cost 20 more dollars than it did last year. Those are just simple things that the country wants. We don't want to be inconvenienced anymore. We just want a smooth life and we want to earn a nice living. And Joe Biden has somehow taken his eye off that ball and he's banging his head against the wall talking about election reform or electric cars or things the country is not even thinking about. And we're over here saying, Joe, over here, pay attention to us. This is what we care about and he doesn't look. And that's why the country is so angry right now. It's like the guy, he's just not paying attention.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: And Emily, what they're doing is demonizing Senators Manchin and Sinema. You think that's going to bring those two Democratic senators into line to vote with their party?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Well, one of the hallmarks of the Democratic Party is that they blame absolutely everyone else but themselves. Whoever has the microphone is blaming someone else. And the whole bad followers versus bad leaders is an example. And another example is blaming Sinema and Manchin, but it doesn't matter because at the end of the day, this administration blames you. We're blamed, regular average Americans, right? The real terrorists in the neighborhood is the one that flies the American flag, right? The real proponents behind this horrible pandemic are the unvaccinated. Whatever it is, it's not them it's us. And I think the numbers that should -- that Biden should pay attention to coming out of those reports are these two. Number one, that the smallest, slimmest minority in this country are the actual liberals. And yet, we see he continues to capitulate to them.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: He continues to think that those are the voices that his policy needs to reflect. And the second data point is that 57 percent of independents disapprove of his leadership and of his administration. And it is those votes that he needs to be calling right now. And those are the moderates, those are the ones in the middle. The reasonable, normal people. And final point, I just find it ironic that in his recent plan, it's going to be about engaging work, "communicating directly with Americans." But as of this point, we have not identified how to do that yet. How about just being honest, bro? Just pick up a microphone and be normal for once. I won't hold my breath.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Well, that will be a fun -- it'd be a fun press conference tomorrow. Democrats using the MLK holiday to attack Republicans as racist.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Democrats using Martin Luther King, Jr. Day to push their voting agenda and attack Republicans. President Biden leading the charge for his party and the media by railing against the GOP and once again, making claims about voter suppression. Watch.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
utterances.utterance: Dr. King wasn't just a dreamer that promised. He was a doer. And on this federal holiday that honors him, it's not just enough to praise him. You must commit to his unfinished work. The attack on our democracy is real.

utterances.speaker: REP. NANCY PELOSI (D-CA)
utterances.utterance: Abraham Lincoln, George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, all of them with tears in their eyes for the departure from our democracy that is happening right now.

utterances.speaker: SEN. RAPHAEL WARNOCK (D-GA)
utterances.utterance: The politicians are trying to cherry pick their voters. It is anti-Democratic. It is anti-American.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Oh, Jesse Watters, I'm so glad we have Nancy Pelosi to translate from legend who have passed away about how they are feeling right now in the afterlife.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm noticing a trend, Emily, and look what happens. So, the black vote put Joe Biden over the top in the primary last time. Did Joe Biden deliver anything for black Americans in 2021? Didn't get Build Back Better, didn't get the election thing. Didn't get anything on police reform, education, healthcare, got zip. But the minute the clock strikes 12 and it's a midterm election year, race card comes down. Republicans are trying to subvert the vote. They're going to try to take away your vote, Bull Connor, Dixiecrat. You hear it all the time. So, what they do is, in the election year, they play the race card to excite the Black base. And then when they're out of power, and it's an off- year, they do nothing for their most loyal constituency. I'm on to them, and everybody else should be. Now, I also read something. He said, Joe Biden, that the Republicans plan to subvert the election. And then crying Chuck said they're rigging the game and rigging the count. Now, I remember when that kind of direct assault on the integrity of an election was deemed censurable. I mean, you couldn't ever say that. You couldn't question the integrity of our democratic institutions. How dare you? But the Democrats are already saying the votes rigged in the midterms and I don't think the Pinocchios have laid a hand on either of those guys. And here's another piece of hypocrisy, Emily Compagno. The Democrats want to federalize the state's election laws, right? But Democrat governors want to fight tooth and nail to regulate their own gun laws, their own state taxes, the way their COVID regulations are, their own health care policies, but they want to take over the state election powers. Which one is it guys? You can't have both.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: That's right. Greg Gutfeld, that happens all the time, the cherry-picking of these rules, the using of it when it -- when it behooves them.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Behooves.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Exactly. I can't get -- I can't do this without saying it at least once. We know that just after saying -- you know, filibustering, for example, right, it was antithetical to the entire bedrock of this country. And then 45 senators used it to rail against sanctions against the Russian pipeline. So, to Jesse's point, what's next, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know. But I admire the fact that you lead this segment with Scritti Politti.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Yes, I did.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A very, very underrated band from the 80s.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: It's so good.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Covered a whole breadth of styles. But can we publish a list of the people that the Dems think aren't racist? And we could put it on a post it note on everyone's fridge. Because I have -- if they could play this game when talking about how the dead would think, OK, you know, I don't think Martin Luther King would be as nearly as far left or even close to far -- this left as the current crop of Democrat leaders. I think he would run screaming with it from them because he was about character, not simply color. He would hope that we've moved on. In the A block, we talked about exploding crime, and B, we talked about the plummeting Democrat numbers. All of this has one thing tied to it and that is the obsession with race and falsely -- Geraldo has talked about this -- falsely framing election reform as a civil rights struggle against bigots. This race card isn't just divisive, for the Democrats, it's energy- draining. You know, instead of helping all Americans, they're just pitting one group against the other. And that's not working. We see right through it.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Kennedy.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Hi. It's interesting because everyone has a hot take here. You know, Joy Reid, says that whoever quoted Martin Luther King who's Republican, they just memorized it in high school. She is incredibly divisive to the point of being disharmonious. You know, if we want harmony, if we want a society that works together, then we need to stop listening to people like Joy Reid. She just flaps her claptrap. And then, you have the other unjoyful Joy Behar saying that it's Republicans who are creating these problems, shoving minority students into failing schools. And I will have her know that the worst schools in the country are in Democrat-led cities where teachers unions have an absolute stranglehold. And the fact that this one size fits all Prussian factory system is still employed, where teachers are unfirable and closes -- schools or unclosable, and parents don't have a choice, that is explicitly racist.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Prussian.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Top that, Geraldo. Top that.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Well, I think that the people that invoke the name of Martin Luther King for a political -- baldface political motive really are lowbrow. Because you cannot invoke that name and what he did and that period for a law that says you have to have a voting ID a voter ID, that every voter has to have an ID. Why is that Jim Crow? Why is Why is requiring -- requesting you to have a voter ID to prove who you are when you vote. How is that George Wallace? How does that Jefferson Davis? How is that Strom Thurmond? You know, it is really beyond the pale. And, you know, I agree about the Joy Reids of the world. There is plenty of room to disagree without labeling, being reduced to labeling your opponent as a racist. Why is that racist, you know, requiring a voter ID? You know, it's just like the Civil Rights issue of our time is black on black crime. Let me hear Joy Reid speak about that once in a while, and then I'll give her more slack.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Geraldo, you said it was low brow, but for Nancy Pelosi, it's very highbrow.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: And she knew Thomas Jefferson personally. So, she actually -- she has some ground here.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: That's exactly right. Yes, she did. OK, guys, stay right there. The CDC tries to clean up their COVID messaging disaster. But did they just make things worse?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Greatest song ever created, Jesse. Admit it or this show stops right now.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I mean, I want -- if the show stops, can I go home?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No. OK. After years of confusion and contradictions, the CDC coming to a sudden realization that their messaging stinks. CDC Director Rochelle Walensky recently doing media training and good for her, and is now admitting to confusing people saying she should have made it more clear that guidelines and recommendations can change quickly, depending on the nature of the virus, which is true. While the CDC tries to regain trust, this doesn't help after telling people to cover up. The agencies finally saying that cloth masks don't do much to stop the virus. Geraldo, I don't see anything wrong here. I mean, when facts change the things you change -- the things you talk about should change, right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: If you -- if you don't change your mind, when the facts change, then you're considered insane. So, I don't know if she's really doing that bad of a job at this point.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I don't know about the last part of that but I -- because I like her. And I think that the problem is particularly with people in my generation, we've been raised to believe everything scientists say, the world is round, the asteroid is not going to hit us. Everything a scientist says we believe in because they know better than we know. They're scientists. It's the -- But the problem is that, as you suggest, the story has been evolving. The virus has been evolving. Nobody could see Omicron coming six months ago when they confidently predicted the end of this horror -- this horror story for the world, five million infected already, But you know, that's our -- the problem is as much ours as theirs, the CDC should be more cautious. They should hedge more. And, you know, she has to stop being so definitive that she gets contradicted a week or two later because then how can you believe.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Kennedy, did we ever believe in cloth masks? I don't know if that's an epiphany. Like, didn't we just assume it was for show?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Anyone who's gotten COVID from wearing a cloth mask, you know it's hot malarkey. Same with the plexiglass partitions, same with the arbitrary six feet of social distancing. They've been wrong on so much that there's no longer -- they no longer have goodwill. They no longer have the trust. She will be fired soon.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: You say when? I say, how soon is now?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes, yes. Take that, Jesse. By the way, Jesse, February 1st is a mere two weeks away, the unofficial end of the pandemic according to the Gutfeld calendar. Do you have any plans? Would you like to celebrate with me?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I would love to celebrate. Not with you, but I'd like to celebrate. Sorry, Greg. It's your sweater. It's eggplant colored.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: It's cute.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I can't be seen with people like that. The question is, why did we trust the government about health in the first place? Do you remember the food pyramid?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The food pyramid said we should be having three to five servings of pasta and potatoes per day, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They also told us that smoking on airplanes was fine. Come on, and they funded gain of function in Wuhan got caught, and then tried to cover it up, and then say, you know what, we -- things have changed. Yes, obviously things have changed. Lewinsky herself said in the spring --

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Walensky.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Whatever. She's going to be fired. I don't have to memorize her name. The CDC director said if you're vaxxed, you cannot get COVID or transmit COVID.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: They did say that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oops. And then what happened? I think this is like the most obese country in the world. COVID preys on obesity. So what did they do? They told everybody to stay home in order seamless and close the gyms, the parks, and the beaches. Greg, I mean, come on. We're supposed to question this stuff? Have you seen who runs the government? People.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Have you met people?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: People aren't very smart.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Wait, I'll stop it. We are also people, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We're very impressive.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And we are taking control of this situation, the American people.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, no, no. We're not in government.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, I mean, American people.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: If got -- no, the people that go into government are not impressive people.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I will agree with you. Walensky, the queen is dead. Another Smith reference. Emily, don't you agree with me? A, that my sweaters awesome, the Smiths rule, and we are in charge. The American people are now declaring, we're kind of done with this, we want to go back to school, we want to go back to work. Screw the government.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Yes, I told you, I complimented you, I like your sweater. I actually thought the opening song was Cry Little Sister from the Lost Boy soundtrack, so I was really excited. But to answer your question, absolutely. But the problem is that the nimbleness and the humility that Walensky, not Lewinsky, Jesse -- that was a -- that was a different person in the White House. That Walensky has said that that she needs to embody and she's sorry about, you know, none of their policies have actually reflected that. So, she said, we developed school guidance, for example, knowing she said that parents and kids and administrators were depending on us to ensure that kids back -- get back into that enriching environment of classrooms. Well, what happened? They haven't changed their policy actually at all. And in fact, they advised the White House directly on how to do that. And because of that, children are committing suicide and in declining mental health at record rates. So, there's a lot more she needs to be held accountable for and that she needs to apologize for. But believe me, humility is definitely not on her attribute list.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, that -- maybe the media training will help. I know it helped Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It sure did.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I got a show.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It cleaned up his acts. He's now getting new wardrobe. I saw them trying to put suits on him. It was quite precious. All right, "THE FASTEST" up next.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Go, Avril. Welcome back. It is time for "THE FASTEST." Anything for little social media street cred. A Canadian woman raising eyebrows after appearing to snap a selfie standing on top of her car while it sank into a river of ice when police were trying to save her. Geraldo, obviously I'm going to go to you first because you're not only America's sweetheart, you're also the Walter Cronkite of our generation. So, I have to ask you. What was more dangerous, this woman standing on top of her car taking a selfie while it's sinking into a river of ice, or your infamous selfie where were shirtless in a towel on the weekend?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Well, let's see that. Let's go to the videotape. No, no, no, no. But as a -- as a person who's addicted to those topless selfies, I give her you know, a little slack that maybe I shouldn't.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Topless?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: But I -- in my own defense, my car is not sinking. So, that's the problem with social media anyway. It's crazy.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: But, Geraldo, you are a legend. And you've not only survived, you thrived.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: And you have two dozen cars, and those are the ones we know about. Emily, you're a fan of international travel and mystery. How many Compagnos would you give this woman on a scale of destruction to legend?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: What -- how many ever equal total Darwinism. This is why there are entire records and archives dedicated to Darwin Awards, i.e. people dying doing dumb things and also selfie deaths. She is lucky that no one was hurt trying to save her dumb self because that's absolutely ridiculous. A million Compagnos, Kennedy.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: A million Compagnos. All right, and, Greg, what do you think of this? I mean, this just seems like very typical millennial behavior. Are they a generation doomed?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: When I look at that, I just think that she is the Statue of Liberty of selfies. She is an amazing -- it's a lifetime -- once in a lifetime moment. And she took -- you know, nobody's asking, how did the car get there? She might be a lousy driver. I'm more upset about that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It looks like a taxi, I think.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: She's giving women a bad name, right, as female drivers. It might be a taxi. I'm very disturbed in other ways that have nothing to do with this.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Well, I think it's pretty fantastic. And you know, it's not as bad, but you know, we've seen people jump into zoo enclosures with tigers and other wild animals. We've seen people fall off cliffs, Jesse Watters. Is a world better off having her still in it?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think so. And if they had had iPhones 100 years ago, people would have been on the deck of the Titanic like --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, man.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: But we never would have had the Heart of the Ocean. "ONE MORE THING" is up next. Stay with us.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's time for "ONE MORE THING." Greg Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Tonight on the "GUTFELD! SHOW," Jim Norton, Jimmy Failla, Dagen, Kat. It's going to be great. OK, let's do this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Animals are great. Animals are great. Animals are great.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I haven't done this in a while. They certainly are great. They don't just look great, America, they also sound great. I want you to listen to Rico, the porcupine snacking on corn.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Look at him. He looks adorable.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't even want to talk over this. It's just so beautiful. It's so beautiful. It's like -- you know what, I wish Dana kind of was here because this would drive her crazy. You know that, right? she Would go insane. Listen. It's so yummy. All right, I'll stop now because people are getting mad.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, let's keep going. Let's keep on listening to that awful sound. All right, Jesse's free -- let's do --- let's do this, Jesse's Feeding Frenzy. All right, so, Lay's potato chips has unveiled what we're calling golden grounds. These are chips made from potatoes that were grown in the dirt from NFL stadiums. These chips are grown from the dirt from Lincoln Financial Field and Philadelphia.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: These are Eagles chips. I think we have turf in that stadium. I don't know how Lay's figured that one out. So, I'm going to try.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: It doesn't taste like victory, does it?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, not this week. But next year, it's going to taste really good.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: That's amazing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, go to Lay's Twitter page @Lay's, I assume, and you can find out how to get the chips that were grown in the dirt --

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- in your stadium.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: In that container. That was amazing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Philadelphia soil. Isn't it fascinating?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Philadelphia soil. It tastes so good.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Philadelphia soil.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Not known for their soil. Geraldo.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Different kind.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Time for Geraldo's Geraldo news with Geraldo. On Monday, here in Northeast Ohio, as you can see behind me, we got over a foot of snow which turns my house into a winter wonderland.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: A mansion.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Some say Narnia. Of course, I had to take the opportunity to play in the snow, make the world's most beautiful snow angel, the oldest man ever to do a snow angel. Roll the tape. Roll the tape.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Cute.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And you kept your shirt on.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: That's right. Erica liked it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She just said she liked it, Geraldo. She says that all the time. Geraldo, I thought your house would be bigger than that. In Ohio, I mean, come on. You got to do better. Emily.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I got rooms I haven't seen.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You're just not allowed in those rooms.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: All right, guys, "FOX AND FRIENDS WEEKEND" co-host Pete Hegseth's new Fox Nation Special spotlights what he explains is one of America's most crucial issues, the miseducation of America. The five-part series examines how the American education system has evolved over the last 100 years leading to the current state of the classroom, including the shift to more progressive content. It is out now on Fox Nation. You can stream it any time at FoxNation.com

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Kennedy, 17 seconds.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: All right, here's a giant frying pan. It's going to the frying pan lodge Museum in Tennessee. It's amazing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You know what? You pulled it off. That's Kennedy.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Amazing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And that's it for us. "SPECIAL REPORT" is up next with Bret. Content and Programming Copyright 2022 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED.
